text:
love this question, and a few different ways to think about "adding value:"

• *make it more convenient.* providing the same information in an alternative format is often enough of a value-add for a simple email gate. I wrote a sprawling 10-part series a few years back and offered a PDF download of the collected series - ended up with a 20% conversion rate without adding anything new
• *add something supplementary.* echoing a few people here - you can augment written content with simple worksheets, calculators, templates, etc. - we used to create a simple branded G Docs asset for every article we created for one customer, and offered it as a gated download (especially nice because each offer is tailored to each article)
• *create something exclusive.* this is the "classic" gated ebook approach, where you create something that can only be accessed via a content gate. research reports, original ebooks, data studies, etc. higher value means higher tolerance for sharing contact details, but also riskier - the contents of your asset might be higher leverage if its public-facing
as everyone points out, always good to sanity check the ratio between perceived value of the download and the amount of sign-up data you ask for

there are so many good enrichment solutions (e.g. Clearbit) that you can use, you can normally just ask for an email and fill in the rest on the back-end

this is the "classic" gated ebook approach, where you create something that can only be accessed via a content gate. research reports, original ebooks, data studies, etc. higher value means higher tolerance for sharing contact details, but also riskier - the contents of your asset might be higher leverage if its public-facing

text: <@U016VHZ0ZD5> Yes, it was a due to the style guide. I’ve rarely used em dashes while working for my current employer, hence I forgot that our style guide specifies spaces should be used. text:
<@U017WA1NKT4> IBM was my first content marketing client, back when I started in 2008. Unfortunately quite a bit of time has passed.

I've gone through tons of Content Strategist interviews though and am glad to share the common themes I've gathered in speaking with quite a few large companies.
